chapters.title: 1. Particulate Nature of Matter
chapters.description: Understanding the composition and behavior of matter at the particle level
learning_objectives: Describe the states of matter and explain their properties
Apply the kinetic particle theory to explain physical changes

topics.title: 1.1 States of Matter
topics.description: Properties and behavior of solids, liquids, and gases
topics.content:
# States of Matter

## Learning Objectives
- Describe the properties of solids, liquids, and gases
- Explain changes of state in terms of kinetic particle theory
- Understand the terms melting, boiling, evaporation, freezing, condensation and sublimation

## Key Concepts

### Solids
- Particles are closely packed in a regular arrangement
- Particles vibrate but cannot move from their positions
- Definite shape and volume
- Cannot be compressed

### Liquids
- Particles are close together but can move past each other
- Take the shape of their container
- Definite volume but no definite shape
- Cannot be compressed significantly

### Gases
- Particles are far apart and move randomly
- Fill their container completely
- No definite shape or volume
- Can be compressed easily
learning_objectives: Describe the properties of solids, liquids, and gases

topics.title: 1.2 Atoms, Elements and Compounds
topics.description: Understanding atomic structure and chemical composition
topics.content:
# Atoms, Elements and Compounds

## Atoms
- Smallest particle of an element
- Cannot be divided by chemical means
- Made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons

## Elements
- Made of only one type of atom
- Cannot be broken down into simpler substances
- Examples: Oxygen (O), Gold (Au), Carbon (C)

## Compounds
- Made of two or more elements chemically bonded
- Have different properties from constituent elements
- Examples: Water (H₂O), Carbon dioxide (CO₂), Sodium chloride (NaCl)

topics.title: 1.3 Atomic Structure
topics.description: Protons, neutrons, electrons, and the nuclear model
topics.content:
# Atomic Structure

## Subatomic Particles

| Particle | Charge | Mass | Location |
|----------|--------|------|----------|
| Proton   | +1     | 1    | Nucleus  |
| Neutron  | 0      | 1    | Nucleus  |
| Electron | -1     | 1/1840 | Shells |

## Key Terms
- **Atomic number**: Number of protons in an atom
- **Mass number**: Total number of protons and neutrons
- **Isotopes**: Atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons
learning_objectives: Describe the structure of an atom
Define atomic number and mass number

topics.title: 1.4 Chemical Formulae
topics.content:
# Chemical Formulae

## Types of Formulas

### Molecular Formula
- Shows actual number of atoms in a molecule
- Example: H₂O (water), C₆H₁₂O₆ (glucose)

### Empirical Formula
- Simplest whole number ratio of atoms
- Example: CH₂O (for glucose C₆H₁₂O₆)

## Ionic Compounds
- Write positive ion first, then negative ion
- Balance charges to make neutral compound
- Example: Na⁺ + Cl⁻ → NaCl
learning_objectives: Distinguish between molecular and empirical formulas

chapters.title: 2. Experimental Techniques
chapters.description: Essential laboratory skills and separation methods

topics.title: 2.1 Laboratory Safety
topics.description: Safe practices in the chemistry laboratory
topics.content:
# Laboratory Safety

## Safety Rules
1. Wear safety goggles at all times
2. Tie back long hair
3. No eating or drinking in the lab
4. Know the location of safety equipment
5. Follow instructions carefully
6. Report all accidents immediately

## Hazard Symbols
- **Toxic**: Poisonous substances
- **Corrosive**: Burns skin and materials
- **Flammable**: Catches fire easily
- **Oxidizing**: Provides oxygen for combustion

topics.title: 2.2 Separation Techniques
topics.content:
# Separation Techniques

## Common Methods

### Filtration
- Separates insoluble solid from liquid
- Uses filter paper and funnel

### Crystallization
- Separates soluble solid from solution
- Involves evaporation and cooling

### Distillation
- Separates liquids with different boiling points
- Uses heating and condensing

### Chromatography
- Separates colored substances
- Uses differences in solubility
learning_objectives: Choose appropriate technique for a mixture

topics.title: 2.3 Measurement and Accuracy
topics.description: Using apparatus correctly and recording measurements
topics.content:
# Measurement and Accuracy

## Common Apparatus
- **Measuring cylinder**: Volume measurements (±0.5 mL)
- **Burette**: Precise volume delivery (±0.05 mL)
- **Pipette**: Fixed volume transfer (±0.05 mL)
- **Balance**: Mass measurements (varies by balance)

## Recording Results
- Write to appropriate precision
- Include units
- Use tables for multiple measurements
- Calculate averages when appropriate

chapters.title: 3. Atoms, Elements and Compounds
chapters.description: Chemical structure and the periodic table
learning_objectives: Describe properties of metals and non-metals
Explain trends in the periodic table

topics.title: 3.1 The Periodic Table
topics.description: Organization and patterns in the periodic table
topics.content:
# The Periodic Table

## Structure
- Elements arranged by atomic number
- Rows called **periods**
- Columns called **groups**

## Groups
- Group 1: Alkali metals
- Group 2: Alkaline earth metals
- Group 17: Halogens
- Group 18: Noble gases

## Trends
- Reactivity increases down Group 1
- Reactivity decreases down Group 17
- Noble gases are unreactive

topics.title: 3.2 Metals and Non-Metals
topics.description: Properties and differences between metals and non-metals
topics.content:
# Metals and Non-Metals

## Metals
- Shiny appearance (lustrous)
- Good conductors of heat and electricity
- Malleable (can be hammered into sheets)
- Ductile (can be drawn into wires)
- High melting and boiling points (usually)

## Non-Metals
- Dull appearance
- Poor conductors (insulators)
- Brittle when solid
- Low melting and boiling points (usually)
- Various colors and states at room temperature
learning_objectives: Compare properties of metals and non-metals
Classify elements as metals or non-metals

topics.title: 3.3 Electronic Configuration
topics.content:
# Electronic Configuration

## Electron Shells
- Electrons occupy shells around the nucleus
- First shell holds maximum 2 electrons
- Second shell holds maximum 8 electrons
- Third shell holds maximum 8 electrons (for first 20 elements)

## Examples
- Hydrogen (1): 1
- Carbon (6): 2,4
- Oxygen (8): 2,6
- Sodium (11): 2,8,1
- Chlorine (17): 2,8,7

## Valence Electrons
- Electrons in outermost shell
- Determine chemical properties
- Used in bonding
